title: FilterRAG: Zero-Shot Informed Retrieval-Augmented Generation to Mitigate Hallucinations in VQA
author: S M Sarwar (University of Maryland, Baltimore County), ...,
relevance_why: This paper presents a method to mitigate hallucinations in Visual Question Answering (VQA), a concept that may be applicable in audio-visual tasks or integrating external knowledge in audio processing contexts.
background: Visual Question Answering (VQA) combines image analysis and natural language processing to produce accurate answers to questions about visual content, often requiring external knowledge.
contribution: This paper introduces FilterRAG to solve hallucinations in VQA by integrating external knowledge sources, achieving improved robustness in both in-domain and out-of-distribution settings.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous VQA methods like ViLBERT often produce incorrect answers when relying solely on internal knowledge.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work enhances the accuracy by combining Retrieval-Augmented Generation with BLIP-VQA, utilizing external knowledge from sources like Wikipedia and DBpedia to ground answers.

key_innovation: Effectively integrates dynamic knowledge retrieval into the VQA process to ensure contextually accurate responses.
real_world_impact: This method holds potential for improved deployment of VQA systems in real-world scenarios where external knowledge is crucial, enhancing user interaction and comprehension.
limitations: No explicit limitations were mentioned in the paper.

new_terms.Retrieval-Augmented Generation: **Retrieval-Augmented Generation** refers to approaches that combine information retrieval from external sources with generative models to create informed responses.
new_terms.out-of-distribution (OOD): **Out-of-distribution (OOD)** refers to inputs or scenarios that fall outside the training dataset distribution, posing challenges for model performance.
